messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: FFB: A Fair Fairness Benchmark for In-Processing Group Fairness Methods

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper introduces the Fair Fairness Benchmark (FFB), a benchmarking framework for in-processing group fairness methods. Ensuring fairness in machine learning is critical for ethical and legal compliance. However, there exist challenges in comparing and developing of fairness methods due to inconsistencies in experimental settings, lack of accessible algorithmic implementations, and limited extensibility of current fairness packages and tools. To address these issues, we introduce an open-source, standardized benchmark for evaluating in-processing group fairness methods and provide a comprehensive analysis of state-of-the-art methods to ensure different notions of group fairness. This work offers the following key contributions: the provision of flexible, extensible, minimalistic, and research-oriented open-source code; the establishment of unified fairness method benchmarking pipelines; and extensive benchmarking, which yields key insights from ùüíùüì,ùüéùüïùüó45079\mathbf{45,079} experiments. We believe our work will significantly facilitate the growth and development of the fairness research community. The benchmark, including code and running logs, is available at https://github.com/ahxt/fair_fairness_benchmark.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "One-network adversarial fairness",
        "Beyond adult and compas: Fair multi-class prediction via information projection",
        "R√©nyi fair inference",
        "AI Fairness 360: An extensible toolkit for detecting, understanding, and mitigating unwanted algorithmic bias, October 2018",
        "Data decisions and theoretical implications when adversarially learning fair representations",
        "Fairlearn: A toolkit for assessing and improving fairness in ai",
        "Optimal transport of classifiers to fairness",
        "Optimized pre-processing for discrimination prevention",
        "Fairness in machine learning: A survey",
        "Fairness without demographics through knowledge distillation",
        "Fair prediction with disparate impact: A study of bias in recidivism prediction instruments",
        "Fair mixup: Fairness via interpolation",
        "Algorithmic decision making and the cost of fairness",
        "Adam: a method for stochastic optimization",
        "Retiring adult: New datasets for fair machine learning",
        "UCI machine learning repository, 2017",
        "Fairness through awareness",
        "Censoring representations with an adversary",
        "Certifying and removing disparate impact",
        "Domain-adversarial training of neural networks",
        "Measuring statistical dependence with hilbert-schmidt norms",
        "Retiring $\\delta \\text{DP}$: New distribution-level metrics for demographic parity",
        "Equality of opportunity in supervised learning",
        "Deep residual learning for image recognition",
        "Pushing the limits of fairness impossibility: Who‚Äôs the fairest of them all?",
        "Wasserstein fair classification",
        "Data preprocessing techniques for classification without discrimination",
        "Fairness-aware classifier with prejudice remover regularizer",
        "Inherent trade-offs in the fair determination of risk scores",
        "Uci adult data set",
        "Propublica compas analysis‚Äîdata and analysis for ‚Äòmachine bias‚Äô",
        "A survey on datasets for fairness-aware machine learning",
        "Kernel dependence regularizers and gaussian processes with applications to algorithmic fairness",
        "Deep learning face attributes in the wild",
        "The variational fair autoencoder",
        "Learning to pivot with adversarial networks",
        "Learning adversarially fair and transferable representations",
        "Costs and benefits of fair representation learning",
        "A survey on bias and fairness in machine learning",
        "Fair ranking with noisy protected attributes",
        "Pytorch: An imperative style, high-performance deep learning library",
        "Scikit-learn: Machine learning in Python",
        "A review on fairness in machine learning",
        "Benchmarking bias mitigation algorithms in representation learning through fairness metrics",
        "Average individual fairness: Algorithms, generalization and experiments",
        "On learning fairness and accuracy on multiple subgroups",
        "In-processing modeling techniques for machine learning fairness: A survey",
        "Fair and optimal classification via post-processing",
        "Fairness constraints: Mechanisms for fair classification",
        "Learning fair representations",
        "Mitigating unwanted biases with adversarial learning",
        "Fairness reprogramming",
        "Age progression/regression by conditional adversarial autoencoder",
        "Inherent tradeoffs in learning fair representations"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in FFB: A Fair Fairness Benchmark for In-Processing Group Fairness Methods, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
